column1: “Nationalism is a great danger for Europe
column2: for all the

column1: European countries. In the history of Europe
column2: nationalism has always meant

column1: wars
column2: and the last great war started right in the heart of Europe… The real

column1: breakthrough
column2: made at the end of World War II is leaving behind nationalism and

column1: national egotisms.”
This is how Professor Valerio Onida
column2: the former president of Italy’s

column1: constitutional court expressed his concern about rising nationalism in Europe
in a televised interview. While nationalism as a cause of war in European
history has been well established
column2: it has been overlooked when politicians and

column1: pundits discuss the Middle East.
What is Nationalism
Nationalism is the political movement that rose in Europe in
the 18th century that led to the emergence of the nation-state. Before
nationalism people did not give their loyalty to the nation-state but to other
different forms of political organization: the city-state
column2: the feudal fief and

column1: its lord
column2: the dynastic empire
column3: or the religious group.

column1: Broadly speaking
column2: two types of nationalism emerged from

column1: Europe – propositional nationalism in Western Europe and ethnic nationalism in
Eastern Europe. Propositional nationalism
column2: also referred to as civic

column1: nationalism
column2: is an inclusive form of nationalism based on individual rights and

column1: the values of freedom
column2: liberty and equality. The oldest form of propositional nationalism

column1: is French nationalism
column2: which is rooted in the French republican ideals of

column1: liberty
column2: equality and fraternity. The French model of citizenship is linked to

column1: belonging to universal republican institutions
column2: not to a specific identity or

column1: religion. When granting full citizenship to Jews during the French Revolution
the Count of Clermont Tonnerre told the National Assembly
column2: “We should grant

column1: everything to Jews as individuals and nothing as a nation.” Classifying
people by their ethnicity is illegal in France
column2: no direct census questions can

column1: be asked that would determine the exact ethnic
column2: racial or religious makeup of the

column1: society. The nation of “liberty
column2: equality
column3: fraternity” treats all

column1: people equally with no differentiation.
The other form of nationalism that emerged in Eastern Europe is ethnic nationalism
column2: it mines race and history to create politics that sacrifice individual liberty to the will of the majority. An example of this type of nationalism is German nationalism
column3: which claims that the true essence of a nation emerges from history
column4: culture
column5: and ultimately
column6: race.

might over-dramatize true incidents
column2: omit important historical details
column3: or add

column1: details for which there is no evidence. These legends and constructed
narratives create imagined communities that give rise to a sense of delusional
inflated self-worth—what Professor Valerio Onida referred to in the opening

that England was the kingdom that

column3: was the

a special mission as representative of the most advanced form of western
culture. And almost always in every national myth there are stories of victimhood
aggrievement
column2: and a sense of superiority. These national myths
column3: along with

column1: irredentism
column2: led Europe into endless wars
column3: culminating in WWII.

column1: Nationalism Arrives in the Middle East
For two thousand years
column2: the Middle East had been ruled by

column1: empires: the Roman
column2: the Byzantine
column3: and the successive Islamic empires
column4: all culminating

column1: in 400 years of Ottoman rule. A multitude of cultures lived side by side
column2: while

column1: people and ideas traveled freely across these vast polyglot empires. By the
19th century
column2: European ideas of nationalism began to spread across the Middle

column1: East.
The First Genocide

Turkish ethnic nationalism came from central and eastern Europe through various channels. Émigré and refugees from Hungry and Poland (as well as Tartar exiles) brought this chauvinistic and illiberal nationalism into the seat of the Ottoman empire. The Armenians and Assyrians were its first victims. The Young Turks
column2: a nationalist movement
column3: in an effort to ‘Turkify’ the new republic
column4: executed a systematic campaign to exterminate the Assyrians and Armenians from eastern Turkey
column5: a plateau they had inhabited for 3
column6: 000 years. As many as 1.5 million people were killed in what is today known as the Armenian Genocide.

column1: Armenians say up to 1.5 million of their forebears were killed in a 1915-16 genocide by Turkey’s former Ottoman Empire
column2: Turkey has the figure at 500
column3: 000 (AFP/Getty) ( AFP/Getty )Turkey has since been locked into never-ending wars with Kurdish nationalists who themselves aspire to create their own ethno-nationalist state on part of the Turkish state.

column1: Arab Nationalism Usurps Syrian Patriotism and leads Syria Into Multiple Wars and Economic Sanctions
Arab nationalism drew inspiration from 19th-century
Western ideas. In 1911
column2: intellectuals from throughout the Levant formed an Arab

column1: nationalist club in Paris where the first Arab congress took place. Later
Damascus became the coordinating center of the Arab nationalist movement. While
the idea did spread to other places like Beirut
column2: Cairo
column3: and Baghdad
column4: nowhere

column1: did Arab nationalism inspire so much passion as it did in Syria
column2: which Nasser

column1: of Egypt would later refer to as “the beating heart of Arab nationalism.” As
Arab nationalists took control of the Syrian government
column2: they preoccupied

column1: themselves with the greater Arab cause. In schools across all of Syria
children stood every morning and saluted the Arab nation
column2: and the green map of

column1: the vast Arab nation replaced the Syrian map in every classroom. Arab
nationalists in Syria were aggrieved and felt betrayed by the West for dividing
their nation with the Sykes-Picot Agreement. But the greatest affront to Arab
nationalists was the creation of the state of Israel that they viewed as
another Western betrayal. Syrians took the mantle of destroying Israel and
resisting the Western plots in the region. This overarching goal led Syria into
multiple wars and economic sanctions
column2: which they wore as a badge of honor.

column1: Arab nationalism asserts that the Arab nation is the group
of people who speak Arabic
column2: inhabit the “Arab World
column3: ” and who aspire to belong

column1: to the same nation. Arabs
column2: Phoenicians
column3: Copts
column4: Assyrians
column5: Berbers
column6: Jews
column7: and

column1: all those who live in the designated Arab world and speak Arabic are the people
of this great nation. But this diverse group of people and cultures
column2: from the

column1: depths of Arabia to the far reaches of North Africa
column2: dress differently
column3: eat different

column1: cuisine
column2: and do not share the same history. The purist Arab nationalists insist

column1: however
column2: that language is the strongest foundation for a nation
column3: arguing that the

column1: varied languages spoken in the Arabic peninsula
column2: the Levant
column3: and in north Africa

column1: are dialects of the same language. But the looser definition of a dialect
states that a dialect should be understood by speakers of other dialects of the
same language without formal training
column2: a test that would be difficult to pass for

column1: someone in the Levant listening to a person from Morocco. Many successful
countries are multilingual
column2: like Switzerland and Singapore
column3: each with four

column1: official languages. And despite the fact that all the contiguous countries of Central
and South America—with the exception of Brazil—speak the same language
column2: and

column1: even share a similar history and religion
column2: none of these countries aspire to be

column1: one nation.
While Egyptians flirted with Arab nationalism during the
Nasser era
column2: they had a deep sense of self as a separate entity
column3: and their

column1: loyalty was to Egypt first. The Egyptian flirtation with Arab nationalism came
to an end with the Camp David accord. Syrians
column2: indoctrinated with Arab

column1: nationalism
column2: viewed the actions of the Egyptian leadership as treasonous and

column1: short-sighted. This view of other Arab leaders as stooges of their Western masters
was a common theme amongst Arab nationalists in Syria. These nationalists
thought that they were the representatives of the pulse and aspiration of the
Arab street. This delusion
column2: however
column3: came crashing down during the past eight

column1: years of war in Syria: that Arab street was pulseless while Syrians were being
killed and their cities destroyed as a part of a brutal
regime change operation to punish Syria for its decades of opposing
the West’s grand plans and defending the honor of their imagined nation.
The Rapture
Another brand of nationalism
column2: Jewish nationalism or Zionism

column1: began in Eastern Europe
column2: it aimed to establish a homeland for the Jewish people

column1: with its sights set on historic Palestine. As of 1920
column2: a British report showed

column1: that there were just over seventy thousand Jewish persons living in British
Mandated Palestine
column2: many of whom had arrived in the preceding 30 years. Jewish

column1: emigration and colonization of historic Palestine continued primarily by
unassimilated Eastern European Jews. In 1948
column2: as Israel declared its

column1: independence
column2: Egypt
column3: Jordan and Syria attacked Israel
column4: and in the 10 months of

column1: fighting that followed
column2: Israel occupied 60% of Palestinian areas—including West

column1: Jerusalem—far beyond the Jewish state allowance proposed by the 1948 Partition
Plan.
This conflict triggered significant demographic change
throughout the Middle East. Around 700
column2: 000 Palestinians fled or were expelled from

column1: their homes in the areas that became Israel and have never been allowed to
return. Over the next several decades
column2: Israel occupied more land from its

column1: neighbors and continued the colonization of Palestinian land. And almost all
the Jewish communities that have colored and enriched much of the Middle East
for centuries in cities like Aleppo
column2: Damascus
column3: Baghdad and Cairo vanished
column4: with

column1: many emigrating to Israel or the U.S.
The refugee camps which sprung up in 1948 became permanent residences in exileIsrael’s Declaration of Independence speaks of equal rights
for all its citizens
column2: Israeli human rights groups have
column3: however
column4: documented

column1: several laws that discriminate against its Palestinian population
column2: which

column1: largely still live separately from its Jewish population. Recently
column2: Israel’s

column1: legislators passed the Nation
State law that says that only Jewish Israelis have the right of
self-determination in Israel
column2: ignoring the rights of its Palestinian citizens.

column1: The Knesset also voted down
the Basic Law Equality bill which proposed that “The State of Israel shall
maintain equal political rights amongst all its citizens
column2: without any

column1: difference between religions
column2: race and sex”. While many of Israel’s founding

column1: fathers were secular
column2: the messianic dimensions of a Jewish state on biblical

column1: land was inescapable. Today
column2: the strongest support for Israel in the West comes

column1: from Evangelical
Christians who believe that for the rapture to occur
column2: the Jews must

column1: return to the promised land.
The Way Forward
After WWII
column2: Europeans realized the ills of nationalism and moved to create a new political structure for the continent. They deemphasized borders between their states
column3: allowing for the free movement of people
column4: workers
column5: goods and services
column6: and created supra-national institutions that service the entire European community. The global financial collapse of 2008
column7: however
column8: exposed serious flaws in the structures of the Euro and other weaknesses in the new post- nationalist European project. The Middle East also has to find its way past nationalism to create stability and bring peace to the region. If not in a union similar to the one being attempted in Europe
column9: then perhaps the answer lies in what Nassim Nicholas Taleb
column10: author of The Black Swan and Anti Fragile calls ‘fractal localism.’

column1: The Rapture is but one of many biblical prophecies. Ammiel
Alcalay
column2: a poet
column3: in After Jews

column1: and Arabs
column2: Remaking Levantine Culture
column3: examines the long and rich relationship

column1: between Arabs and Jews
column2: and between the three monotheistic religions in the Levant

column1: that predated nationalism. He ends his work by quoting Shmuel Trigano:
When Isaiah announced “In that day
shall Israel be a third with Egypt and with Syria
column2: a blessing in the midst of

column1: the land…Blessed be Egypt my people
column2: and Syria the work of my hands
column3: and Israel

column1: my inheritance” he was certainly not predicating a union or a fusion into a
state
column2: an empire
column3: but the opening into a space for three people passing beyond

column1: a stage of belligerency
column2: of the state
column3: the leaping beyond formal boundaries.

column1: Mr. Alcalay continues:
Somewhere between visions based on
the old prophecies and the need for a new covenant
column2: between closed doors and

column1: full streets
column2: the magic of old places and the locked rooms without song
column3: a

column1: space remains
column2: a space for a poetics and a politics of the possible.

Throughout the Syrian war
column2: the Southern Province of Sweida
column3: in coordination with the Syrian army
column4: had succeeded in protecting itself against the jihadist attacks on the province’s Western border with Deraa
column5: and on the Eastern flank
column6: adjacent to the Syrian Desert.

column1: By the end of summer 2018
column2: as the war seemed to reach an end in Southern Syria
column3: the local paramilitary units were partially demobilized. The Syrian army units stationed in Sweida’s Desert were redeployed to the southwest of Deraa
column4: where they joined the fight against an Isis enclave nestled at the foot of the Israeli controlled Golan Heights.

column1: The demobilization was a fatal mistake. On July 25
column2: at dawn
column3: hundreds of Isis fighters emerged from the Eastern Desert. They carried out a coordinated attack marked by suicide bombings
column4: shootings
column5: and stabbings targeted mainly at the Eastern villages overlooking the Syrian Desert. The poorly armed local villagers
column6: men and women
column7: from 12 besieged villages fought bravely against the invaders
column8: but six villages succumbed to the fundamentalist group as it carried out door-to-door massacres with the help of some local Bedouins.

column1: The attack had two objectives. The first was to force the Syrian army to halt its offensive against the Isis enclave in Deraa. The second was for ISIS to provoking a massive exodus from the Druze Mountains.
Within less than two hours
column2: hundreds of Druze fighters rushed to the targeted areas
column3: killing more than 80 ISIS members. Dozens of Druze fighters from Mount Hermon and from the Damascene suburbs of Jaramana and Ashrafiet Sahnaya arrived that same day and joined the combat. The besieged areas
column4: including the six ambushed villages
column5: were liberated by the end of day
column6: boosting the morale of the local population. More than 250 civilians and local Druze fighters lost their lives and another 250 people were injured
column7: in what has become the bloodiest day for the province since the beginning of the war.

column1: Over the next few days
column2: the army dispatched hundreds of soldiers and armored units
column3: before launching a major counterattack in the Eastern Desert. By September
column4: ISIS had lost more than 3000 square kilometers of land
column5: and became completely encircled in al-Safa hills
column6: a 250 square kilometer volcano in the middle of the desert east of Sweida.

column1: ISIS lost the Sweida battle but managed to capture 31 Druze hostages: 20 women and 11 children.
The local fighters found and rescued a woman who had managed to escape in the desert
column2: while a second woman
column3: shot in the head by the fundamentalist group
column4: died.

column1: For the next three months
column2: the hostage issue became the major political
column3: social and humanitarian concern in the Province of Sweida. ISIS conditioned the release of the abductees to the withdrawal of the Syrian army from the Eastern Desert
column4: the neutrality of the Druze
column5: the release ofISIS fighters and their relatives
column6: and the payment of ransom. Damascus and the Druze delegation in charge of the hostage issue systematically rejected ISIS’ conditions
column7: as they would have put the Druze Mountains in harm’s way and strengthened the fundamentalist group. As a result
column8: ISIS killed two of 29 Druze hostages. Muhannad Abou Ammar
column9: a 19 year old university student
column10: was beheaded on August 1.

column1: An older lady
column2: Tharwat Abou Ammar
column3: was shot on October 1. Another 65 year old captive died in custody. The video of the beheading and the pictures of Tharwat’s body covered in blood
column4: published online by ISIS
column5: angered the local population. They were aimed at putting pressure on the government.

column1: On October 19
column2: six Druze hostages were liberated in exchange for the release of 17 women (ISIS relatives/wives) held by the Syrian government
column3: as well as a dozen Bedouin captives that had been kidnapped by some local Druze fighters in the aftermath of the July 25 attacks.

column1: This was the first part of a negotiated agreement between Damascus and ISIS that also included a ceasefire in the Eastern Desert of Sweida
column2: where the Syrian army has been fighting ISIS for the last three months with the help of Russian air force. According to some estimates
column3: between 800 and 1000 ISIS fighters are now surrounded in the Safa volcanic field in the desert.

column1: However
column2: the truce collapsed on November 3 in addition to the second part of the deal that stipulated the liberation of seven Druze women and three children in exchange for the release of 35 ISIS relatives. The group demanded the release of 35 fighters from government custody
column3: but was met with rejection since the initial deal only included civilians.

column1: ISIS has had recent military success in Hajin near the Euphrates city of Deir ez-Zor
column2: where it has killed some 327
column3: US-backed fighters belonging to the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces since the beginning of the military operation there in September. ISIS has regained self-confidence and launched several assaults from the Safa Volcano
column4: before being quickly rebuffed. On November 5
column5: the Syrian army started deploying considerable reinforcements around the volcano
column6: which consists of a plateau of black rocky hills where ISIS has not only been able to successfully resist for more than a month
column7: but even launch deadly attacks against Syrian troops
column8: killing more than 400 Syrian soldiers in the last three months. The Fourth Army Division (one of the toughest) and the Fifth Corps (advised by Russian officers) have deployed alongside Hezbollah units and the Palestine Liberation Army for the upcoming battle against ISIS. The impressive military buildup intimidated ISIS and forced the group to renegotiate.

column1: On November 8
column2: Syrian State media said that the government troops have freed all remaining Druze hostages kidnapped by ISIS. The army’s operation occurred in a remote area Northeast of Palmyra. However
column3: some analysts believe that the liberation of the women and children was part of a prisoner’s deal exchange.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: the Syrian army launched a new assault against Isis on Thursday in the Safa hills. According to a member of the Druze delegation in charge of the hostage issue
column3: there have been a few disagreements between the Americans and the Russians who were assisting the Syrians in the negotiations with ISIS. The Russians wanted to transfer all ISIS fighters from the Safa Volcano to the north of the Province of Hama
column4: a region currently controlled by Hay’at Tahrir al-Sham (ex-Nusra
column5: affiliated to al-Qaeda)
column6: while the Americans wanted to gather them in the Hajin region.

column1: The refusal of Washington to cooperate with the Syrians and the Russians in the battle against ISIS has left a hole through which ISIS has been able to operate. The Americans have forbidden the Syrian army from penetrating within a 55 km radius buffer zone surrounding their military base in al-Tanf
column2: 120 km east of the Safa Volcano. This base sits on the strategic Damascus-Baghdad highway. Damascus has declared this buffer zone problematic as it is preventing the Syrian army from cleaning up the area. The government believes the buffer zone is being used by Isis to move its troops undercover between Northern and Southern Syria
column3: and between Syria and Iraq.

column1: In Northern Syria
column2: the US-backed Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) have halted their military campaign against Isis after suffering heavy losses in the Hajin area in the Euphrates and following clashes against Turkish forces in Northern Syria. The Kurds
column3: who lead the SDF
column4: are focused on their struggle against the Turkish army after President Erdogan announced his intention to eradicate the SDF.

column1: This leaves ISIS with enough room for maneuver to regain influence either in the Euphrates or along the Syrian-Iraqi border. The United States’ refusal to cooperate with the Russian and the Syrian armies might be counterproductive with the absence of troops on the ground capable of eradicating Isis.
Damascus also accuses Washington of training Isis fighters converted to moderate rebels
column2: such as the Pentagon-backed Jaysh Maghawir al Thawra. The Syrian government is asking Washington to either contribute to its anti-Isis campaign in the Syrian Desert
column3: or leave the area and let the Syrian army clean up the desert all the way to the Iraqi border.

column1: On October 29
column2: Syria’s foreign minister Walid al-Moallem declared that “under the pretext of supporting Syrian Kurds
column3: the U.S. has established bases in the North of Syria and a base in al-Tanf in the South
column4: which are in reality used to reorganize ISIS terrorists to fight the Syrian Arab Army (…). What for? Because they want to prolong the Syrian crisis in Israel’s interests”.

column1: US officials have declared that al-Tanf base serves as a launching pad for counter ISIS operations
column2: even though the US coalition has never been involved in any effort to eradicate ISIS to the south of the Euphrates Valley
column3: such as when ISIS invaded Palmyra
column4: the suburbs of Damascus
column5: and the Province of Sweida.

column1: Washington maintains its base in Tanf as leverage in any future negotiations with the Russians. Its strategic goal is to stop Iran from establishing an East-West land corridor stretching from Tehran to Beirut that serves as an arms supply route to Hezbollah.
After the Syrian army and the Iraqi Popular Mobilization Units cleaned ISIS out of most of the desert
column2: the US base in al-Tanf is becoming obsolete as an anti-ISIS tool. Sooner or later
column3: Washington’s choice of maintaining Tanf will risk helping ISIS
column4: rather than hurting it.

column1: by Robert G. Rabil – @robertgrabil
October 30

The emergence of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia is inextricably associated with the Wahhabi school of Islam. The Saudi-Wahhabi pact goes back to the eighteenth century when Sheikh Muhammad ibn ‘Abd al-Wahhab (1703-1792)
column2: the founder of the Wahhabi-Salafi school of Islam traveled to Diriya
column3: the stronghold of the Saudi tribe
column4: and struck a deal with its chief. The pact served the interest of both parties by expanding their respective political and religious influence throughout the regions of Najd and Hijaz.

column1: Basing his ideas on the writings of classical Salafi scholar Ibn Taymiyyah
column2: al-Wahhab rejected shirk (idolatry
column3: polytheism) and bid‘ah (heretical religious innovation)
column4: which he believed permeated the holy land of Islam. He believed in the return to the authentic ways of the salaf al-salih (pious ancestors) and advocated tawhid (oneness/unity of God) and transcendence of God. He called for unity and the purification of Islam. His puritanical movement became known as the Muwahhidun. Significantly
column5: he justified leveling the charge of takfir (unbelief) on those he considered engaged in shirk. For example
column6: the failure of Muslims to observe all the pillars of Islam was tantamount to committing kufr (unbelief). His definition of tawhid centered on Muslims’s exclusive worship toward God alone. In other words
column7: it was Kufr to associate any other being or thing in the Worship of God.   This constituted for him the divide between Islam and kufr
column8: and between tawhid and shirk.

column1: In this respect
column2: the Shi’a
column3: and their offshoot sects such as Alawis
column4: Ismailis
column5: and Zaydis
column6: were considered as the worse of mushrikoun (polytheists) for they have associated worshipping God with venerating the infallible descendants of Prophet Muhammad. More so
column7: Shi’a traditions
column8: among other Islamic and non-Islamic traditions
column9: such as tawassul (supplication)
column10: Shafa’a (intercession of prophets and Imams)
column11: tabarrruk (seeking of blessings) and ziyara (visiting the tombs of venerated religious figures) only deepened the Wahhabi identification of Shi’ism with polytheism and idolatry. The corollary of this identification made warfare against Shi’ism a Wahhabi religious duty.

column1: Between the years 1794-1802 the Saudi-Wahhabi movement destroyed many holy shrines in today’s Iraq
column2: including the Prophet Grandson Imam Hussein’s shrine in Karbala in 1802. Imam Hussein’s martyrdom in 680 at the hands of Umayyad Caliph Yazid at Karbala was most formative for Shi’a ideology and tradition. This martyrdom became central to Shi’a identity
column3: tradition
column4: and theology because it epitomized Imam Hussein’s opposition to tyranny
column5: oppression
column6: and the struggle against the chronic injustices of the world.

column1: During the campaign (1902-1932) of Saudi chief Abd al-Aziz to conquer Najd and Hijaz thousands were killed and maimed
column2: including many Shi’a. In 1927
column3: Wahhabi scholars issued a fatwa (religious edict) calling for the expulsion of Shi’a from al-Ahsa in the Eastern province of Saudi Arabia unless they consented to the destruction of their mosques and their conversion to Wahhabism. This anti-Shi’a religious strand became the official view of the monarchy when King Abd al-Aziz proclaimed the establishment of his kingdom in 1932 and made Wahhabism its official religious establishment.

column1: Correspondingly
column2: the Shi’a
column3: as a minority in the kingdom comprising around fifteen per cent of the population and residing mostly in the oil-rich Eastern Province
column4: have been religiously and institutionally discriminated against. Their religious customs
column5: including Ashoura commemoration of the martyrdom of Imam Hussein
column6: were forbidden
column7: the publication and distribution of their religious texts were outlawed
column8: their call to prayer banned
column9: and their centers of religious studies closed. No less significant
column10: they were vilified in textbooks.

column1: The early expression of their grievances was manifested in their heavy participation in the 1950s in the labor riots of the oil fields managed by the Arabian American Oil Company (Aramco). The riots were brutally suppressed by the Saudi National Guard. Subsequently
column2: apparently inspired by the success of the Iranian revolution in 1979
column3: Shi’a demonstrated in the Eastern province. The government violently suppressed the demonstrations
column4: arrested Shi’a leaders and forced a number of Shi’a activists into exile. It was at this time that a cleric Sheikh Hassan al-Saffar
column5: supported by the followers of religious scholar Mohammad al-Shirazi
column6: established the opposition group the Organization of the Islamic Revolution (Munazzamat al-Thawra al-Islamiyya).

column1: Saudi harsh treatment of their Shi’a community began to change in the 1990s
column2: following the invasion of Kuwait by Iraq and the deployment of American troops to the Kingdom. This change apparently stemmed no less from American deeper involvement in the Middle East than from the failure of both Saudi policy of oppression and Shi’a policy of protestation. Sheikh al-Saffar changed the name of his organization to al-Haraka al-Islahiya (Reform Movement)
column3: and in 1993 a leader of the Shiite opposition in exile
column4: Tawfiq al-Sayf
column5: led a large delegation of Shia to meet with King Fahd. Meaningfully
column6: King Fahd conceded to some Shi’a demands including permitting them to practice previously banned religious rites
column7: some Shi’a to return from exile
column8: and to guarantee the safety of those returned. Significantly
column9: the King ordered the revision of a school text book that had referred to the Shi’a as a heterodox sect. The new edition added the Twelver Shiite School of Islam to the four Sunni schools of Islam.

column1: This slow and circumspect yet important transformation in the relationship between the monarchy and its Shi’a community gained momentum following the American liberation of the Shi’a from the yoke of Saddam Hussein’s oppression in 2003. Many Shi’a activists signed a statement
column2: titled “Partners in the Homeland
column3: ” and submitted to Crown Prince Abdullah. The statement emphasized the loyalty of the Shiites to the Kingdom and called for their integration into Saudi society by removing institutional and social discrimination against them. Moreover
column4: when the Crown Prince became King in 2005
column5: many Shiite leaders and clerics went to the capital to pledge their allegiance to him. Many Shi’a believed that the new King would turn a new page in his relationship with the Shi’a community at large.

column1: It’s noteworthy
column2: however
column3: that a minority of Shi’a
column4: including the militant group Hizbollah al-Hijaz
column5: opposed Shi’a engagement with Saudi authorities. The kingdom has designated Hizbollah al-Hijaz as a terrorist organization and blamed it for several terror acts
column6: including the 1996 Khobar Towers bombing. Conversely
column7: many Wahhabi religious scholars maintained their disparaging views of the Shi’a and opposed any rapprochement with them. Even Saudi religious reformer Sheikh Safar al-Hawali disparaged the Shi’a and called the Shi’a Islamist party Hezbollah of Lebanon the party of the devil.

column1: King Abdullah had to walk a fine line between improving the conditions of the Shi’a
column2: opposing what he saw as Iranian encroachment across the Middle East
column3: and curbing the power of his religious establishment that stood as a hurdle to his reforms. He focused on bolstering the Kingdom’s defenses
column4: enhancing scientific research
column5: fighting al-Qaeda
column6: and curbing the power of the Wahhabi religious establishment as a precondition to enunciate significant reforms. He removed a popular Wahhabi cleric
column7: Sheikh Saad Bin Nasser al-Shathri
column8: from the country’s High Council of Religious Scholars because he criticized the king’s decision to allow male and female researchers to work together in the newly established mixed gender King Abdullah University of Science and Technology. Similarly
column9: he sacked the head of the Commission for the Promotion of Virtue and Prevention of Vice
column10: whose puritanical agents try to enforce the behavioral application of Islamic law. Significantly
column11: he tried to break the monopoly of the power of Wahhabi clerics within the Council of Senior Scholars
column12: who issue official religious rulings
column13: by including in the 21-member Council representatives of all four schools of Sunni Islam (Shafi’I
column15: Maliki and Hanafi schools of jurisprudence). Though he did not include in the Council any Shi’a cleric
column16: he increased Shi’a representation in the Consultative Assembly of Saudi Arabia.

column1: Shi’a cleric Sheikh Nimr Nimr.
Unfortunately
column2: King Abdullah’s reforms not only came to a screeching halt but regressed following the eruption of Arab Revolutions across the Arab world. Protests erupted in the Eastern province few days after widespread protests started in Bahrain on February 14
column3: 2011. The province is only a 30-minute drive across the causeway from Bahrain. In a show of force
column4: the Saudi interior minister Prince Muhammad bin Nayef vowed to crush the protests with an “Iron Fist.” In the following days and months
column5: Saudi authorities clamped down on the protests
column6: killing a number of them
column7: and arresting dozens of them including the preeminent Shi’a cleric Sheikh Nimr Nimr.

column1: In the meantime
column2: feeling threatened by the swift spread of Arab revolutions
column3: the monarchy felt the need to be further legitimized by the religious establishment. On March 6
column4: 2011 the Council of Senior Scholars issued a fatwa acclaiming the rule of Saudi royals and banning demonstrations. Excerpts of the fatwa read:

column1: The Council praises Allah Almighty for what He has bestowed upon the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia with unity of words and action on the basis of the book of Allah and tradition of the messenger
column2: under the wise leadership of legitimate allegiance… Since the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia is based on the Qur’an
column3: Sunnah
column4: the pledge of allegiance
column5: and the necessity of unity and loyalty
column6: then reform should not be by demonstrations and other means and methods that give rise to unrest and divide the community…The Council affirms prohibition of the demonstrations in this country…It is what practiced by the Prophet (peace be upon him) and followed by his companions and their followers.

column1: Since then
column2: in order to maintain absolute power
column3: the monarchy has renewed its firm commitment to its Faustian pact with the Wahhabi religious establishment. This resolve for maintaining absolute power has taken a critical dimension with the ascension to power in 2015 of King Salman and his son crown prince Muhammad bin Salman
column4: who essentially managed to wield effective power in the kingdom. On January 2
column6: Sheikh Nimr
column7: along with 47 Saudis
column8: was executed for being convicted of terrorism offences. Sheikh Nimr was a vocal critic of the monarchy. But he was not a terrorist.

column1: This is the background against which Prince Muhammad launched his so-called campaign of reforms
column2: which have been no more than a window dressing to his attempt at modernizing and controlling the Kingdom. Fundamentally
column3: Muhammad’s reforms have not introduced any systemic change to the Kingdom’s austere social structure and laws. Under the pretext of fighting corruption
column4: he detained dozens of princes and wealthy Saudis so that he could clip their wings and take a hefty portion of their fortune. He arrested the women activists who campaigned for allowing women to drive. He kidnapped Lebanon’s Prime Minister for not being tough enough on Hezbollah. He has waged a brutal war in Yemen initially foregrounded in Wahhabi proselytizing among Zaydi Shi’a. He arrested dissenting scholars. And most recently
column5: he most likely ordered the gruesome dismembering of the journalist Jamal Kashoggi for being critical of his policies.

column1: Clearly
column2: Prince Muhammad does not tolerate any form of dissent. His absolute power rests on his ability to both check the power of his family members and to maintain the loyalty of the religious establishment. Washington cannot influence the Kingdom’s religious establishment
column3: but it can prod the royal family to remove Prince Muhammad from power in the interest of the welfare and reputation of the Kingdom. In 1964
column4: the royal family forced King Saud to abdicate in response to his blunders. At the same time
column5: the Trump administration should use the inexcusable murder of Kashoggi to persuade the Kingdom to renew the path of slow but steady systemic reform that began under late King Abdullah. As such
column6: Washington can better maintain its strategic relationship with Riyadh. Otherwise
column7: the Trump administration
column8: besides forsaking its moral compass
column9: will definitely make United States complicit in Prince Muhammad’s present and future misfortunes and catastrophes involving Sunni-Shi’a sectarianism and a possible war with Iran instigated as much by Wahhabi theological views of Shi’ism as by geopolitical considerations.

Interview with Lebanon’s Minister of Refugee Affairs, Mouin Merhebi,"By Michael Gerini
Residing in the north of Lebanon
column2: Mouin Merhebi is a member of Saad Hariri’s Future Movement. A staunch opponent of Hezbollah and the Assad government
column3: he currently serves as Minister of Refugee Affairs (officially “Minister of State for Displaced Affairs”) in the Hariri government
column4: a position he has held since December of 2016. Though coming into the position with little experience in the matter
column5: Meherbi’s active lobbying on behalf of the refugees and his adamant stance on refugee return has won him the praise of several NGOs and the U.N.

column1: With the Syrian Civil War seemingly approaching its end
column2: the Minister’s position and the administration of his bureaucracy will become even more important. Though severely strained by possibly over two million Syrian refugees
column3: Lebanese infrastructure and society have managed the crisis well. The next test for Lebanon will be for it to manage the orderly and peaceful transition of Syrians back to their home country.

column1: Minister Merhebi was kind enough to share his opinions and outlook with me in an interview conducted in Beirut in April of this year.
There is some disagreement regarding the actual number of Syrian refugees in Lebanon. Some put the number at just over one million
column2: others at two million. I would like to know what is the best count that your ministry has of the number of Syrians actually in your country?

column1: Well the count is about one million but we have about 500
column2: 000 who are not registered. The difference in numbers is due to not having those people in camps. When they came into Lebanon they did not come through official crossings. So that’s why. But according to the U.N. agencies and the UNHCR
column3: the registered are about one million and adjusting for uncounted people in remote areas
column4: we have one to two.

column1: One to two million?
So that’s at 1.5 [million].
Initially
column2: there was a decision made not to put them into camps. Why was that decision made?

column1: When those people first fled
column2: it was from killings and torture. They were forced into being refugees
column3: they were trying not to be killed
column4: [trying to protect their] families
column5: children. They did not agree with our [Hezbollah-backed] government [which is why they crossed illegally rather than through official border crossings]. So they ran across the border from their cities and we were not prepared
column6: we did not know about it [ahead of time]. We tried to help them individually
column7: not officially
column8: not through our government at that time. It took time to really understand how big the problem was
column9: that the crisis was huge. Later on
column10: all the U.N. agencies
column11: our government
column12: the NGOs
column13: and other nations tried to help. We did not have tents
column14: we had our houses. We put them into our homes just to shelter them. Later on we had internal political problems inside Lebanon. Some of our parties did not want to let those people live in camps. They feared that the same issues that happened with the Palestinians will happen with the Syrians. We are a small country with a small population. We are 4.2 million within 10
column15: 452 km2 so you can understand the issue.

column1: Absolutely. You mentioned the various U.N. agencies that are working with you. It seems that government efforts have been somewhat haphazard. Has the U.N. helped in terms of organizing
column2: not just their own efforts
column3: but government efforts?

column1: No
column2: the U.N. agencies have not organized government efforts. No. We had some issues stemming from our internal problems. We had to deal with that and it took time. The perception may be such
column3: but really from the first—let me tell you
column4: PM Saad Hariri’s cabinet had resigned and it took six months to get a new cabinet. During these six months we did not do things the right way because we did not have a cabinet at the time. Later on
column5: we got a cabinet with PM Mikati—it was a Hezbollah cabinet. Hezbollah did not want to deal with this issue positively. So myself
column6: I had many problems with this cabinet. I always called on this cabinet to help those people
column7: to build camps for those people so that we could help them in a positive way—most of all to know where those people are living. Sometimes we are not able to send food because we don’t know where they are. Things went much better with the cabinet of PM Salam. And now with this cabinet
column8: we have made a new Ministry for refugees. By the way
column9: we call it “displaced” [in reference to the title “Ministry of State for Displaced Affairs”] because in Lebanon we do not like to [include Syrians within] the same problem as the Palestinians
column10: who since 1948 have been living in Lebanon. But we deal with them [Syrians] as refugees
column11: let me tell you frankly.

column1: This is different from the Palestinian crisis because the Syrians
column2: unlike the Palestinians
column3: have a country to go back to. It seems that across the political spectrum in Lebanon the intention is to send the Syrians back. Is that the official stance of this Ministry?

column1: Let me tell you: Regarding the return of the Syrians
column2: they should willingly return under the supervision of U.N. agencies. We will not force those people to return. We cannot guarantee those people’s safety if we [force them to] return them to their country. So they have to decide themselves to return. We are not going to interfere with the situation. We have not made any statements saying that we will force people to go back to Syria. And we will not.

column1: So you won’t take a more internationally-facilitated return?
It is a direct responsibility of the U.N. to take action on this issue. So if there are safe places where they can build homes
column2: or build camps for them
column3: it is those refugees’ decision to return and with U.N. help and U.N. cover. We as the government of Lebanon cannot take any forced action towards those people’s return to Syria. We cannot do it. We are a member of the U.N. and we will not do this. There are some major principles and we are abiding by those principles and laws.

column1: Conversely
column2: that might mean that Lebanon will have to tolerate a large
column3: semi-permanent refugee population from Syria?

column1: We have been coordinating this issue since 2011. This is an issue of human beings. It’s not an issue of trade or whatever. They are people
column2: like me and you. So you cannot treat them as if you are not aware of this issue or do not know about this issue. We have had a lot of problems with Syrians and Syria used to govern our country. Their soldiers tortured us
column3: their soldiers shot at our cities. Our government was controlled fully by the Syrian government
column4: by Hafez al-Assad and Bashar al-Assad. But this issue is about human beings and we cannot deal with this issue as if we are avenging what they did as torturers and destroyers in Lebanon. These refugees—they did not do this to Lebanon. They are not responsible for what their government did to Lebanon. We are dealing with this issue from a humanitarian side.

column1: I’m struck by the human face that you are adding to this issue
column2: in contrast to the responses heard from other ministries who only focus on the numbers and talk about the one million
column3: 1.5 million
column4: two million
column5: etc.

column1: With the Palestinians
column2: yes there are two million
column3: plus some Iraqis. But it is something human
column4: nothing else.

column1: It’s remarkable that you would take a step back from the numbers when we are talking about two million foreigners
column2: compared with a population of four million.

column1: Fifty percent or above.
It’s an impressively large number. And you think that return should be absolutely voluntary?
We cannot send somebody to be killed or we would be criminals
column2: and we are not criminals. We are not.

column1: In terms of Lebanon’s future
column2: if a large part of the Syrians stay
column3: what will be their status? Will they ever be integrated into Lebanon?

column1: No
column2: not at all. This situation will not allow it in any condition. And when things get better in Syria
column3: I think the refugees will be eager to return. Fifty percent of those people are living below $2 per day [inside Lebanon
column4: now]. How can they continue living this way? If they are able to go back to their houses
column5: their lands
column6: to build a new future with new hopes
column7: I’m sure the conditions in Syria will be much better for them. I don’t think there will be a mass of them not willing to return to Syria. If you go and ask a young Syrian student
column8: “what do you want?” He will tell you directly: “I want to go back to my house in Syria
column9: to my land in Syria. I want peace.” That’s it. Let me tell you
column10: those Syrians
column11: I respect them very much. They used to come every Thursday in the afternoon and go back to Syria on Friday afternoon. Do you know why? They used to have demonstrations on Friday after prayer at twelve. The demonstrations used to be finished at four or five o’clock. So they used to send their wives
column12: their children to Lebanon on Thursday to safeguard them. They used to get them back after the demonstrations
column13: just to keep them safe. When we would ask them “Why don’t you stay a little bit
column14: just to be sure there are no shootings or anything?” They would tell us
column16: we are eager to go back and we cannot keep our lands and our houses from those criminals.” So when you are moving every week for eight months and going back every week
column17: and going back to your house
column19: what do you think about those people? Just a mother taking her children with her—two
column22: twenty years old—what do you think about those people? Well I have full respect for them. Till now they are thinking about their return
column23: I’m sure they are eager to go back now and not tomorrow.

column1: And just one final question concerning the future of the region
column2: Lebanon and Syria in particular. Do you think that Syria
column3: post-conflict
column4: can learn lessons from post-conflict Lebanon
column5: with how well this nation is doing comparatively?

column1: Yes
column2: sure
column3: and everybody should learn from each other and for sure as neighbors we are learning from each other. I think things will go much better when this criminal Bashar al-Assad
column4: this butcher
column5: will be out of Syria
column6: him and his regime
column7: those killers. The Syrians will be able to live in peace
column8: to rebuild Syria. Those people are not Daesh
column9: they are not al-Qaida
column10: and they are for sure not the worst criminal ever on earth: Bashar al-Assad. He killed maybe 500
column11: 000 of his people and destroyed all his cities. Now 50% of his people are refugees in other countries. What a shame for everybody
column12: for the world
column13: for the international community. So if we can
column14: if we are able to help them find peace
column16: it will be for the best for the region
column17: for the best for the whole world. That’s why we are fighting those butchers and ISIS and al-Qaida. This is the right way
column18: to force peace in Syria and to stop this war
column19: to stop the killing. We are not enabling ISIS or al-Qaida to recruit for their militias if we find a solution for Syria.

column1: What is needed most of all now is to really find an end for this war
column2: but at the same time to try to help those people. They need help. The Lebanese have a small country with a debt of $75 billion up to now
column3: according to the World Bank. This issue cost Lebanon with a debt of $75 billion about $18 billion as assessed by the World Bank. We cannot really help anymore. The international community should help Lebanon to help these people
column4: which at the same time will help the international community. Without this
column5: we are really going to have significant international problems that will affect the whole world and not only this region. Thank you.

column1: Absolutely. Thank you.
Michael Gerini is an independent journalist who focuses on Middle Eastern and US politics.

The Game Above the Game
by David W. Lesch
For Syria Comment – Sept 21

The various combatants in and around Idlib seem to have hit the pause button for the time being.  What just a short time ago appeared to be an imminent onslaught by Russian and Iranian supported Syrian government forces to take back one of the last areas outside of the control of Damascus
column2: accompanied by widespread civilian casualties and refugees fleeing the battleground
column3: now has given way to high stakes diplomacy.

column1: The key is Turkey.  The Turks have been the dominant power in northwestern Syria along the border and down through the province of Idlib for a number of years since the fall of Aleppo to the opposition early in the Syrian civil war.  Indeed
column2: in some ways
column3: with Turkey establishing shared power grids
column4: training local police forces
column5: rebuilding and staffing schools
column6: and investing in the local economy
column7: northern Syria functionally looks more like southern Turkey nowadays. This process actually started years before the beginning of the civil war when a honeymoon in relations between the two countries led to heavy Turkish investment in Syria
column8: economic integration
column9: and an expansion of Turkish cultural markers.

column1: Since the civil war began
column2: however
column3: Ankara has supported the many stripes of the anti-Assad coalition in this part of Syria
column4: including elements of the Free Syrian Army and a plethora of jihadist groups.  At first
column5: Turkey was committed to the fall of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad. As it became clear
column6: certainly since the Russian military intervention on behalf of the Syrian government in 2015
column7: that Assad was going to remain in power
column8: Turkey’s objectives in Syria shifted to making sure empowered Kurdish groups
column9: many of whom Ankara has labeled terrorists
column10: were unable to establish autonomous zones
column11: especially along the Turkish-Syrian border. The most powerful Kurdish fighting force has been backed by the US as part of the Syrian Democratic Forces in its attempts to roll back and eliminate the presence of the Islamic State in Syria
column12: a dynamic that has

column1: Enter Russia—or more to the point
column2: Vladimir Putin.  The Russian president’s foray into Syria has proven to be quite successful in the short term.  He was able to keep Assad in power and
column3: therefore
column4: maintain
column5: indeed significantly enhance
column6: Russian strategic assets in the heartland of the Middle East.  By way of this intervention
column7: he has orchestrated Russia’s return as a major diplomatic player in the region
column8: probably even more so than the US at the moment.  And because the US early on decided to team with the Kurds
column9: who had the best available indigenous fighting force to take on the Islamic State
column10: therefore alienating an increasingly autocratic Turkish President Erdogan
column11: perhaps he could even find the holy grail and pluck a disenchanted Turkey away from the US and NATO and into Russia’s orbit—a potential strategic coup of enormous proportions. As a result
column12: Russian-Turkish relations have greatly improved in recent years after some early hiccups
column15: and Turkey have become the working group in the so-called Astana process
column16: which for several years has monopolized attempts to de-escalate the war in Syria.

column1: What has emerged is a very tense diplomatic game focusing on Idlib.  Everything would be much easier if Turkey would have just withdrawn from the area.  Certainly
column2: this is what Russia and Syria were hoping for
column3: especially as it appeared the Turks had backed themselves in a corner with no easy way out.  The Syrian government and the Russians would like nothing better than to just batter Idlib into submission
column4: a strategy that has worked elsewhere in the country. But Turkey abandoning Syria was never going to happen. Erdogan has invested too much political capital—and two full-fledged offensives—in northern Syria to just give up.  His domestic position politically is not as solid as it once was
column5: especially as his economy continues to plummet
column6: so admitting defeat by leaving Syria is not an option.

column1: Perhaps this is why the Syrians and Russians built up their forces in the area and began a targeted aerial assault
column2: i.e. to intimidate Turkey into taking the path of least resistance out of Syria. Instead
column3: it appears that Erdogan
column4: stiffened by the timely support of and tough talk from the US and some of its European allies
column5: has called the Russian bluff.  He has sent more men and materiel to reinforce existing observation posts in Idlib and moved more forces toward the border.

column1: Erdogan is basically saying the following to Putin:  if there is an all-out Syrian-Russian offensive
column2: Turkish troops will be killed
column3: with possibly a direct Russian-Turkish military confrontation that could even involve the US in support of its recalcitrant NATO ally.  This would all but end Putin’s dream of reeling in Turkey and perforce push Ankara back toward the US—the Kurdish issue notwithstanding.

column1: Putin blinked.  And now there has been a Russian-Turkish agreement to find another way to resolve the situation in Idlib short of war.  He’s giving Erdogan a face-saving way out of his morass while possibly solidifying his relationship with him.  Somehow Turkey will fudge the separation of legitimate Syrian opposition forces from the jihadists
column2: such as the al-Qaida-linked Hayat Tahrir al-Sham
column3: after which time perhaps there can be a joint effort to eradicate the “terrorists.”  This will be easier said than done as the estimated 10
column4: 000 jihadists in Idlib have nowhere to go and will dig in.

column1: I can’t imagine Assad likes this deal at all
column2: as it consecrates Turkey’s position of influence in the north. He wanted to pummel Idlib and gain more territorial control over his country
column3: but his depleted forces can’t do it without substantial Russian help.  He has to go with the Russian diplomatic game right now
column4: perhaps waiting until it might inevitably breakdown—or until the next UN General Assembly session is over in September
column5: when international diplomacy focuses elsewhere while he incrementally picks away at the edges of Idlib both militarily and through reconciliation agreements. Maybe this is also what the Russians have in mind. They too would like nothing better than to eliminate jihadists in Idlib
column6: a number of whom are Chechen and from other areas in Russia who have caused problems for Moscow in the past.  They want to dig the graves of these hardened jihadists in Syria rather than have them return to Russia.

column1: Right now
column2: though
column3: the diplomatic games are being played above those in Idlib itself
column4: many of whom are anxiously awaiting their fate—and are at the whim of leaders who have anything but their fate in mind.

column2: TX and author of the upcoming book

Loyalty over geography: Re-interpreting the notion of ‘Useful Syria’ — By Matthias Sulz,"Loyalty over geography: Re-interpreting the notion of ‘Useful Syria’By Matthias Sulz *
For Syria Comment: Sept. 6
As the offensive to reconquer Idlib starts
column2: it is useful to recall that the notion of ‘Useful Syria’ as geographic reference to the population-rich axis of Aleppo-Homs-Damascus
column3: as well as the coastal areas of Latakia and Tartus
column4: does not accurately reflect the regime´s intention of reconquering all of Syria. This makes the Idlib offensive not the end of the civil war
column5: but merely its next stage that will be followed by further regime manoeuvring and fighting to retake the country´s north and east. It makes more sense to reconceptualise ´Useful Syria´ in terms of loyalty
column6: i.e. as reference to the regime’s policies to consolidate its power by rewarding loyalty and punishing ‘betrayal’.

column1: The term ‘Useful Syria’ was popularised by analysts in July 2015 after a deal between the regime and rebels was struck to end the siege of al-Fuah and Kafraya
column2: two towns in Idlib in the north-west of Syria. The Shiite population of the two cities was exchanged with the population of the Sunni towns of Madaya and Zabadani near Damascus
column3: cities that had also been besieged by the Syrian regime. Since then
column4: it has become a shorthand reference to the Aleppo-Homs-Damascus axis
column5: as well as Syria’s coastal regions
column6: with the implication that
column7: in a pinch
column8: the regime would consider restoration of its control over these areas as an acceptable outcome of the war. In a candid speech on 26 July 2015
column9: Syrian President Bashar al-Assad in fact conceded that the Syrian army could not guard every spot of Syrian soil because otherwise more crucial areas would be infiltrated by ‘terrorists’
column10: endangering their stability. But Assad did not use the words ‘Useful Syria’ to refer to these territories. Rather
column11: four minutes later into the same speech
column12: he stressed that all regions of Syria are equal and that the regime does not discriminate
column13: but that military exigencies require a temporary preference to defend the more strategically important areas first.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: Western analysts soon framed a kind of ‘Useful Syria’-doctrine that would supposedly guide the Syrian regime´s strategy to consolidate its grip over said parts of the country[1] and of Iran to connect Hezbollah’s strongholds in Lebanon with Syria’s coastal region.[2] This
column3: however
column4: ignored the repeatedly and publicly stated intent of the regime to take back ‘every inch of Syria’.[3] Tellingly
column5: the term ‘Useful Syria’ has  not once been employed by the Syrian regime’s itself. The only article in Syrian state media that refers to this concept heavily criticizes the notion and sees it as a US invention aimed at splitting up Syria and to maintain its military base in al-Tanf on the Syrian-Iraqi border.[4] So
column6: where does the term ‘Useful Syria’ come from if not from the Syrian regime?

column1: Historically
column2: ‘Useful Syria’ meant something different. Around 1920
column3: the French used it in a bid to maintain control over today’s Syria and the petroleum resources of Mosul while renouncing their claim to ‘Greater Syria’
column4: which included Palestine and Jordan. At the time
column5: Palestine and Jordan were considered ‘Useless Syria’. As it happened
column6: the French Prime Minister Clemenceau in the end also had to surrender the Mosul region to his British counterpart
column7: Lloyd George
column8: under intense pressure
column9: but managed to retain 23
column10: 75% of the shares of what would later become the Iraq Petroleum Company for the ‘Compagnie française des pétroles’ (now Total).[5]

column1: More recently
column2: the French journalist Georges Malbrunot used the expression ‘Syrie utile’ in an article in Le Figaro in 2012[6]
column3: predicting that the Syrian regime might have to withdraw to the country’s economic and population centres. In making his case
column4: Malbrunot took a page from the French colonial playbook in Algeria: keep control over economically relevant regions as basis for fighting a long war of attrition against internal ‘enemies’.

column1: The dichotomy of useful/useless (utile/inutile) is well known to the French as they widely practiced it during their colonial rule in Africa. The French aimed to control cities at the coast as well as resource-rich regions in the periphery (‘Afrique utile’) while marginalizing economically irrelevant regions (‘Afrique inutile’).[7] French policy in Morocco is a good example of this practice: the French focused on controlling the urban centres of Rabat and Casablanca but left the Rif region to its own devices
column2: the effects of which can still be felt today.[8]

column1: When one applies this economic approach to Syria
column2: it is self-evident that the agriculture
column3: oil and phosphate-rich regions of Palmyra and Deir Ezzor in the east of the country will not be considered ‘useless’ by the Syrian regime as their revenues are significant.[9] That the Syrian military fought to regain those regions before advancing south and towards Idlib is telling. In short
column4: the geographical and economical notion of ‘Useful Syria’ only makes sense when including the resource-rich eastern parts of the country. But this makes practically all of Syria ‘useful’
column5: rendering the notion analytically impractical.

column1: A more helpful way of applying the notion of ‘Useful Syria’ discards its geographical connotations
column2: and views it in loyalist terms instead. Through population- and ceasefire deals the regime re-established social control over reconquered areas and made them ‘useful’. Inhabitants were given the option to remain
column3: or to move to rebel-controlled areas such as Idlib. Those that remained know that they are under government surveillance. The climate of fear that has been created by mass disappearances
column4: torture and executions has further battered them into submission. The resulting ‘loyalty’ will help prevent future uprisings. Further loyalist strategies for creating a ‘Useful Syria’ that the regime applies include considering those that fled military conscription as having lost a right to return
column5: [10] imprisoning returning refugees viewed as disloyal and rewarding loyalists with contracts to rebuild destroyed cities and giving them preferential housing access. Finally
column6: some areas in Syria have been selectively depopulated of Sunnis
column7: which strengthens the regime´s support base in strategic locations.[11] In terms of loyalty these areas are now ‘useful’ to the Syrian regime
column8: as the risk of a future uprising has been decreased.

column1: In summary
column2: when thinking about the Syrian regime’s war fighting strategy
column3: two things are worth keeping in mind. First
column4: the Syrian regime does not limit itself to a geographical notion of a ‘Useful Syria’ in the sense of the Aleppo-Homs-Damascus axis and the coastal regions. Instead
column5: the resource-rich east is part and parcel of its reconquest. This means that Assad’s repeated announcements to take back every inch of Syria need to be taken at face value. The regime’s military preparations for the campaign on Idlib are in full swing and negotiations with Syria’s Kurds and the Syrian Democratic Council have commenced to agree on a roadmap that would see regime cooperation in the provision of utilities and services. That the US presence in al-Tanf is a thorn in the Syrian’s regime flesh is no secret. In the longer term
column6: Syrian military advances on al-Tanf and the adjacent areas of the Syrian-Iraqi desert where remnants of ISIS pursue their activities can be expected.

column1: Second
column2: the regime shores up loyalty by instilling a climate of fear in reconquered regions as well as in areas that never rose against it. In reconquered areas
column3: the regime moreover engages in selectively permitting refugee and IDP return based on perceived loyalty. This re-population tactic is key to decrease the risk of future uprisings. International reconstruction policies and aid should be mindful of it.

Introduction

The purpose of this article is to provide a critique of the Rojava project through a close examination of the discrepancies between the rhetoric surrounding the endeavour and the realities governing its implementation. By “Rojava project” we refer to the endeavour to establish Kurdish nationalist sovereignty in northern Syria by the Democratic Union Party (PYD) and its military wing the People’s Protection Units (YPG)
column2: later transformed into the Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF). Our substantial focus is on the ways in which Kurdish nationalist leaders and parties in Syria and Iraq have simultaneously oppressed Assyrians—revealing the fundamentally ethnocentric and nationalistic nature of the politics behind the Kurdistan project in both countries—and co-opted Assyrians in order to propagandise the supposedly ethnically-inclusive nature of their politics. We will also examine the rhetorical
column3: political
column4: and media strategies behind the Rojava and KRG projects
column5: particularly in relation to Assyrians. The particular geographical focus of our analysis is “Rojava”
column6: but an analysis of Kurdish politics and the fate of the Assyrian people requires a transnational perspective. The “Dawronoye” (“Revolutionaries”)
column7: an Assyrian political movement which operates under PYD and PKK control
column8: will be assessed as a force serving to advance Kurdish nationalist interests in Syria and Iraq and to burnish the rhetoric surrounding those interests. The participation of the Dawronoye in the Rojava project and the SDF—backed by a substantial rhetorical and media strategy—and the readiness of western governments to accept them as valid representatives in order to ethnically “pluralize” the SDF and legitimize them as an ally means a comprehensive account of the nature
column9: operations and capabilities of the Dawronoye is needed.

column1: Our thesis is that the policies of Rojava’s Kurdish self-administration and its Assyrian proxy
column2: the Dawronoye
column3: are actively harming the prospects of Assyrian survival in Syria. In support of that thesis
column4: we document a range of abuses by the Kurdish self-administration and the Dawronoye
column5: which include:

column1: Extensive harassment and intimidation of Assyrians who resist the policies of the Kurdish self-administration
Physical violence committed by both the PYD asayish and the Dawronoye Syriac Military Council (MFS) security forces against Assyrians
Forced conscription and parallel tax systems
The imposition of Kurdish nationalist ideology through an overhaul of the education system
Attempts at land confiscation and the annexation of Khabur by Kurdish nationalist forces
Manipulation of rhetoric and propaganda that seek to fully absorb the Assyrian experience into the Kurdish nationalist cause as articulated by the PYD/YPG
column2: paving the way for the long-term absence of any Assyrian representation outside or apart from the Kurdish self-administration.

column5: and being towed in the eastern Mediterranean in support of Assad’s forces was a stark reminder of this reality.  So how did Russia win—and why did the US fail over and over again?

column1: There is one outstanding difference in the Russian versus American military interventions in internal national conflicts in the Middle East:  in Syria
column2: the Kremlin supported the entrenched state. In Afghanistan
column3: Iraq
column4: Libya
column5: and Syria
column6: the US supported opposition forces seeking the overthrow of the entrenched state.

column1: For the sake of argument
column2: let’s say the US and NATO reversed their policy and actually wanted Libyan President Muammar Gadafi to remain in power against the opposition forces unleashed by the Arab spring. Is there any doubt that with US military support he would still be in power today?  Perhaps he too would be mopping up pockets of resistance much as Assad is doing today in Syria.  However illogical or immoral it may have seemed at the time to most in the West
column3: let’s say Washington wanted Assad to stay in power seven years ago when the Arab spring hit Syria. Would not the US be the one crowning its success there
column4: not Russia? Ironically
column5: the US supported the Iraqi state against ISIS—and won.  But the US is not going to get much credit for solving a problem it largely created when it dissolved the state via the invasion of Iraq in 2003 and its chaotic aftermath.

column1: The US can overthrow just about any government in the world or keep one in power if it sets it mind to it.  That’s how overwhelming its military might is. The US could have removed Assad if we really wanted to.  The problem is that the Middle East security state
column2: by its very nature
column3: constructs a ruling apparatus and governance system that is pervasive. It is one that becomes very good at preventing the development of any viable
column4: coherent opposition movement
column5: usually through a combination of divide and rule tactics and repression.

column1: If the government is overthrown
column2: as it was in Afghanistan
column3: Iraq
column4: and Libya
column5: there is very little left to take its place. New governments were brought to power by external forces
column6: therefore lacking indigenous legitimacy
column7: with little experience in politics (especially democratic politics).  What inevitably results is rampant instability
column8: with more people as time goes on willing to accept the return of authoritarianism if it will keep the lights on
column9: the grocery stores stocked
column10: and suicide bombings at a minimum.

column1: In Syria
column2: the Assad government had more legitimacy than most gave it credit for—or at the very least it was adept at convincing a number of groups in a war weary population that it was their best bet moving forward.  This was particularly true of minority groups in the country as the Sunni Arab-dominated opposition became more jihadist as the war deepened.  Although the top echelons of the Syrian military and intelligence apparatus are disproportionately composed of Alawites
column3: there are also a number Greek Orthodox
column4: Druze
column5: Sunnis
column6: Catholics
column7: and Armenians in decision-making positions
column8: offering and reinforcing in practical terms to many Syrians an alternative model to the monotone jihadist one. Compared to many other armies under pressure from the Arab spring uprisings
column9: the Syrian military remained relatively cohesive and continued to fight. And perhaps it is not so much that the Assad government had more legitimacy then we imagined from the outside
column10: it is that the largely fractured opposition had less. Recall that the Syrian government recognized by most in the West (and in the Arab world) in the early days of the civil war was led by the Syrian National Council
column11: made up mostly of exiled Syrians who lacked any sort of legitimacy inside the country among the armed opposition actually doing the fighting and dying.  This seemed to mimic the famously disastrous playbook the US employed in Iraq
column12: i.e. relying on exiles who lacked standing among the real power brokers in the country itself.

column1: In addition
column2: the Assad government had a myriad of existing patron-client networks
column3: network building knowledge
column4: and well-honed co-optation tactics
column5: especially with prominent Sunni families and tribes established over decades of constructing a neo-patrimonial state. It will be difficult for the Syrian government to re-establish and maintain its patrimonial position in a clientelist network altered by the socio-political landscape of over seven years of war—and the concessions it made to keep many Syrians on its side—but this networking dynamic proved to be vital in terms of the scores of local reconciliation agreements the government entered into with opposition elements
column6: largely negotiated by members of the government’s intelligence apparatus.  The longer the state hung on and provided even a modicum of state services
column7: and the more it advanced militarily after the Russian intervention
column8: Assad’s perceived legitimacy began to grow simply because he was seen as the only viable alternative to many Syrians. And he is being increasingly seen as the only viable alternative by the US
column9: Israel
column10: Saudi Arabia
column11: and others
column12: who are now more focused on making sure the Iranians are kept at bay in Syria rather than removing Assad.

column1: Officials in these countries have been taking a diplomatic beeline to Putin to accomplish this. On this issue
column2: all roads lead to Moscow. Instead of having to create a government out of a jumbled mess as the US attempted to do in Iraq and Afghanistan (and to a lesser degree in Libya)
column3: a halfway functioning state is already in Syria through which Russia has regained a central position in the country and in the region. This is not to say that the US should always back the entrenched state in similar circumstances
column4: but recent history clearly suggests it should better understand the challenges of going against it.
